documents.content: Lightning flashed through the castle window, before the sky returned to darkness and rain. I trudged down the hallway, my candle flickering in invisible drafts from the stormy chill outside. Suddenly the candle lit up a face! "Evening, squire," said Bertram, the care-taker. "You startled me," I said, though I was glad he was there. I'd started to investigate the mystery of the scarecrow mask, and there were a lot of questions. It was a small Scottish castle, miles away from the nearest town. Behind a large wooden door in the front, I discovered the whole first floor was a single, enormous room. Dark stone staircases led on either side to an open second floor, which was filled with shiny armor from the Middle Ages. It felt like the ghostly bodies of knights, preserved for centuries and now left on display. Above that was a dark top floor, which Bertram had converted into rooms for guests. But unfortunately, he'd only attracted three paying customers. "And now I've lost me prime exhibit," he wailed. Two of his guests emerged from their room - Mr. and Mrs. Winfrey. The elderly couple had heard our voices, and were wondering if Bertram was serving dinner. Mr. Winfrey was a large man who looked like he'd enjoyed many dinners. But Mrs. Winfrey just seemed unhappy to be so far from home, especially in a castle where it rained all day, complete with its own spooky mystery. "I'll tell you how it began," Bertram said, as we gathered around a long wooden table downstairs. Bertram's son Chester had prepared a traditional dinner in the cook's quarters outside. As we munched on roasted chicken and potatoes, Bertram described a fierce battle that never was. "The sheriff was searching for a dangerous outlaw," he said. "He'd watched the roads, and searched the fields, and determined that he must be hiding here, in this very castle. He sent for the king's soldiers, who responded with 100 men, each armed with swords and spears. That dangerous outlaw would not escape their justice.” Lightning flashed outside. "They searched the first floor - but he was not here. They searched every suit of armor - but he was not there. And then they searched the rooms on the third floor. But there was no trace of him. From dawn they searched, and through dusk they searched, but the outlaw was never found.” Mrs. Winfrey seemed confused, and she'd obviously never heard the legend before. "Where was he?" she asked. "He was right here the whole time," Bertram warned. "He watched them come, and he watched them go. At any time, he could've reached out and touched them.” "He stood out in the field, in front of them, in plain sight. But he'd dressed himself as a scarecrow. All through the day he stood, arms stretched out on either side, like an innocent straw man propped up to frighten away birds.” We all laughed, and Bertram most of all. "It's what made this castle famous!" he chuckled, "And I've loved that story since I was a boy.” "When I came here I vowed I'd preserve what became known as 'the Castle of the Scarecrow,' along with its heritage," he said seriously. "Amid all the armor upstairs, there's just one piece that the tourists will come to see - the mask of that outlaw scarecrow. "But now it's gone!" Silence filled the room, as we heard the rain beat against the door. "That's outrageous," said Mr. Winfrey. "We've traveled over 3,000 miles just to see that mask! My re-telling of that legend could make me a best-selling author.” Mrs. Winfrey added proudly that her husband was writing an exciting book about the history of famous outlaws, then sighed that she was just along for the trip. I wondered if she was miserable enough to sabotage the castle's prime exhibit. Bertram explained the crime. The scarecrow's mask stood on a pole at the center of the armor exhibit upstairs - as though surrounded by the armor of knights that it had fooled. Twenty minutes ago, shortly before opening the exhibit, Bertram entered the floor, only to see that pole standing conspicuously bare and empty. "Maybe the scarecrow's ghost took it," said a sharp voice from the stairway. A well-dressed man descended, the third guest at the rainy castle. "I'm proud of my family tree," said Charles Kincaid, defiantly. "And of all the generations that went before, there was only one who achieved infamy in the pages of history. He was a sheriff - yes, that sheriff. And he lived the remainder of his life in disgrace for failing to catch that notorious outlaw. Everywhere he went, people whispered about his tremendous failure - outwitted by a silly mask and some straw.” There was more rain, and more lightning, as Charles entered the dining room. Anticipating my thoughts, he announced, "No, I didn't steal the mask, but I wish I had. And I'll tell you one thing more. I hope you aren't able to find it, any more than my sheriff ancestor found your hidden outlaw.” Chester laughed at Bertram's obvious dismay as he carried in a pecan pie that he'd prepared in the cook's quarters, and I began the search for clues. It was eerie to stand surrounded by empty suits of ancient armor, but it soon paid off. Bertram and I discovered a trail of footprints that led to the stairs. Your thief came from outside, I told Bertram, who seemed surprised. "But it's a cold, rainy, and windy night. Who would want to leave a cozy castle for an evening like this? I can't be sure, but I didn't notice any of my guests having wet hair.” Each guest agreed to let us search their room. Bertram searched through all of the bags that Mr. Winfrey had brought, along with his room, but there was no sign of the scarecrow's mask. And while Charles Kincaid had two fine suits hanging in his closet, a search of his room, his suits, and his pockets all failed to turn up the scarecrow's mask. "Perhaps the king's soldiers have been fooled again," he sneered. If the thief hadn't traveled upstairs, perhaps he'd headed downstairs? There were no clues on the east staircase, but on the west staircase, my candle illuminated a strange, white scrap, which was wet and slimy. I tilted my candle to the floor, and discovered. . . a potato peel. As though having a second dinner, everyone gathered around the table downstairs. I announced I'd determined who'd stolen the scarecrow's mask.

original_metadata.reveal_text:
"I bet the thief is Mrs. Winfrey," teased Charles Kincaid.
"How could that be?" I answered. "When Bertram told the story of the scarecrow, she didn't even know the story about where the outlaw had hid!
"But we've also eliminated suspects by searching your rooms," I continued. "We were able to deduce that none of the guests have the mask.
"And for that matter, the thief came from outside.” Eyes darted suspiciously around the room.
"And finally, the thief appears to have some familiarity with. . .”
"Potatoes," finished Bertram. The room was silent as his face lit up with understanding.
"Potatoes," echoed Chester. "I hope you enjoyed them," he told the guests sheepishly.
"It must be cold and unpleasant, living in the cook's quarters in back of the castle," I said. "I can't blame you for wanting to sabotage the tourist trade. But your shoes got wet just walking to the castle - and your left a trail of footprints that led from the scarecrow's pole.”
"If I'd known you were so unhappy, I could've hired a local cook," said Bertram gently. "My only regret is you felt that you had to lie to me.
"Yours was the one room we didn't search," Bertram continued, now with understanding. "I wondered why you laughed at dinner when Charles said that we'd never find the mask.”
"Perhaps the castle's new 'sheriff' was outwitted by his outlaw son," Charles teased.
Bertram stood for a moment, and then roared with laughter. And we all joined in.

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. First identify who, among the five people known to be on the grounds, could have come in from the outside on that stormy night.

   •  Mr. Winfrey, Mrs. Winfrey and Charles Kincaid all lodged in the guest rooms on the third floor.  
      – When Bertram met me in the corridor he had just come from the third-floor landing; the corridor carpet was dry.  
      – None of the three guests had wet hair or damp clothing when we met them a few minutes later.  
      – Therefore none of the guests had just returned from the outside.

   •  Bertram himself was with me from the moment the theft was discovered.

   •  Chester alone lives in the detached cook’s quarters “out back.”  
      – For every meal he must walk through the rain to reach the castle.  
      – If anyone left wet prints on the stone floor, he is the natural candidate.

2. Examine the physical clues.

   •  Trail of wet footprints: proves the mask-thief had come in from outside.  
      – Only Chester routinely approaches from outdoors; the others had stayed inside all evening.

   •  Scrap of wet, slimy potato peel on the west staircase:  
      – The peel could only have come from the kitchen preparations a short while earlier.  
      – The only person who had handled raw potatoes that evening was Chester (he served roast chicken and potatoes).

3. Check concealment opportunities.

   •  The three guest rooms and Charles Kincaid’s clothing were searched at once – no mask found.  
   •  Bertram, the caretaker, was with the detective the whole time after the discovery.  
   •  Chester’s private quarters were never searched; they are outside the main castle and therefore beyond the range of the hasty room-to-room inspection.  
   •  Chester laughed appreciatively when Kincaid taunted Bertram that the mask would never be found – an unconscious tell.

4. Consider motive.

   •  Chester lives alone in a cold, damp out-building and earns little although he does all the cooking.  
   •  Fewer tourists would mean less work and might force his father to sell the mask to a collector, generating money the family needs.  
   •  Sabotaging the star attraction achieves both ends.

5. Eliminate other suspects.

   •  Mr. Winfrey knows the story and covets the mask for his book, but he never left the castle (dry hair, dry shoes, no footprints).  
   •  Mrs. Winfrey did not even know the legend; no motive and also no opportunity.  
   •  Charles Kincaid would like the mask lost for reasons of family pride, but he likewise never stepped outside and his rooms and pockets were empty.

Conclusion: every physical trace points to Chester; all others are contradicted by the footprints, the potato peel, and the room searches.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Bertram the caretaker, Chester the cook, Mr. Winfrey, Mrs. Winfrey, Charles Kincaid
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Chester (Bertram’s son and the castle cook)
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
Between preparing the chicken and potatoes and serving dessert, Chester slipped back outside into the rain, entered the castle through the main door, climbed the west staircase to the armour gallery and removed the famous scarecrow mask from its pole. He tucked it under his coat, came back down the west stairs—dropping a wet bit of potato peel that clung to his sleeve—crossed the hall and exited to the rear. His wet shoes left the trail of footprints that the detective later followed. Chester hid the mask in his own quarters, then returned by the usual kitchen entrance, dried himself quickly and carried in the pecan pie as though nothing had happened. He felt safe because no one was likely to demand a search of the draughty little cook’s hut.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•  Bertram was with the detective from discovery onward and never left the castle that night.  
•  Mr. Winfrey was dry and his luggage and room were searched immediately—no mask.  
•  Mrs. Winfrey had no knowledge of the legend, no incentive, and likewise was dry; her room was searched.  
•  Charles Kincaid’s rooms and clothing were searched; he never left the building (hair and shoes dry) and no mask was found.  
Only Chester had wet shoes, access from outside, the tell-tale potato peel, an unchecked hiding place and a plausible motive; therefore the others are exonerated.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
detection.reveal_segment:
"I bet the thief is Mrs. Winfrey," teased Charles Kincaid.
"How could that be?" I answered. "When Bertram told the story of the scarecrow, she didn't even know the story about where the outlaw had hid!
"But we've also eliminated suspects by searching your rooms," I continued. "We were able to deduce that none of the guests have the mask.
"And for that matter, the thief came from outside.” Eyes darted suspiciously around the room.
"And finally, the thief appears to have some familiarity with. . .”
"Potatoes," finished Bertram. The room was silent as his face lit up with understanding.
"Potatoes," echoed Chester. "I hope you enjoyed them," he told the guests sheepishly.
"It must be cold and unpleasant, living in the cook's quarters in back of the castle," I said. "I can't blame you for wanting to sabotage the tourist trade. But your shoes got wet just walking to the castle - and your left a trail of footprints that led from the scarecrow's pole.”
"If I'd known you were so unhappy, I could've hired a local cook," said Bertram gently. "My only regret is you felt that you had to lie to me.
"Yours was the one room we didn't search," Bertram continued, now with understanding. "I wondered why you laughed at dinner when Charles said that we'd never find the mask.”
"Perhaps the castle's new 'sheriff' was outwitted by his outlaw son," Charles teased.
Bertram stood for a moment, and then roared with laughter. And we all joined in.
